newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Rao caught in legal tangles.
newsitem.headline: India's Rao caught in legal tangles.

text.p: Former Indian prime minister P.V. Narasimha Rao, who was briefly arrested on forgery charges late on Wednesday and then immediately released on bail, has been named in several corruption cases.
Following are summaries of the three cases in which Rao, who served as prime minister from mid-1991 until last May, has either been charged or is under investigation.
ST KITTS

The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), India's federal police, charged Rao and three others on September 26 in a forgery case involving an alleged attempt in 1989 to defame V.P. Singh, an opposition leader who later became prime minister.
The case involves the alleged falsification of bank documents to show that Singh's son, Ajeya Singh, had a secret bank account with $21 million on the Caribbean island of St Kitts.
At the time V.P. Singh, who had left the ruling Congress party for the opposition, was spearheading an anti-corruption campaign against the government.

V.P. Singh became prime minister at the end of 1989 after Congress lost general elections. Authorities later cleared Ajeya Singh of allegations that he had violated foreign exchange and anti-corruption laws.

The federal police agency said the four accused were charged with criminal conspiracy, forgery, giving false evidence and using forged documents. The charges carry a maximum sentence of seven years in jail.

On October 4, an Indian judge issued a warrant for Rao's arrest and scheduled a hearing for October 14. The Delhi High Court suspended the warrant pending a ruling on a request by Rao for legal protection against arrest.

On October 9, the Delhi High Court granted Rao the right to pay pre-emptive, or anticipatory, bail to prevent being taken into custody before the lower court hearing set for October 14. At that hearing he can request ordinary bail.
Late on October 9, federal police served the arrest warrant on Rao at his New Delhi home. He immediately paid a total of 50,000 rupees ($1,400) in bail and was freed.
Rao has not commented publicly on the case.
CHEATING SCANDAL
An Indian expatriate businessman, Lakhubhai Pathak, alleges Rao and a Hindu guru named Chandraswami conspired to cheat him of $100,000 in 1983.

Pathak claims he paid money to Chandraswami in an unsuccessful attempt to win a state newsprint contract after Rao, then foreign minister, assured him at a meeting in a New York hotel that his "work will be done".

In July, a Delhi judge summoned Rao to appear in court to face charges. Rao lost two appeals to have the summons overturned. A judge upheld the summons on September 21, and ordered Rao to appear in his court on September 30 to face charges.
The former prime minister, who quit as Congress party chief hours after the judge's ruling on September 21, was later denied legal protection against arrest.

On September 30, the Supreme Court exempted Rao from having to appear in court until it considers a police request for a change in venue from a local court to a more secure location. The Supreme Court has not yet ruled on the police request.
The lower court has scheduled a hearing for October 16 but must await the Supreme Court decision before selecting the venue.
The lower court was expected to charge Rao with criminal conspiracy to cheat, which carries a maximum penalty of seven years in jail.

If arrested and denied bail, he could be put under judicial or police custody pending trial. Newspapers said a local state-owned hospital was prepared to take in Rao, who has diabetes and heart problems.
The two other co-accused, Chandraswami and his personal assistant, are both under custody in New Delhi's Tihar jail pending trial.
Rao has said he is innocent and has denied he was in New York on the dates mentioned by Pathak.
VOTE-BUYING SCANDAL
Lawmakers of the regional Jharkand Mukti Morcha party said they were paid $100,000 to vote against a 1993 no-confidence motion which Rao's Congress-led government survived by a wafer-thin margin.
Earlier this year the CBI filed a case accusing Rao and other Congress leaders of buying the votes. They have denied any wrongdoing. The case is still under investigation.
